title: 111_hr6415
content: The "Tax Relief Certainty Act" repeals the sunset provisions of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 and the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003. This Act ensures permanent tax relief by removing expiration dates on certain tax provisions. Section 303 of the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003 is repealed. The Secretary of the Treasury must submit any necessary changes to the Internal Revenue Code within 90 days. Title II provides permanent individual Alternative Minimum Tax relief. The Alternative Minimum Tax exemption amount for taxpayers other than corporations is modified under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The exemption amount varies based on filing status and calendar year. The Alternative Minimum Tax exemption amount for taxpayers is modified based on filing status and calendar year. The exemption amounts differ for individuals, married individuals filing separately, surviving spouses, and estates or trusts. The term 'surviving spouse' is defined in section 2(a) and marital status is determined under section 7703. Taxpayers described in paragraph (1)(A) for tax purposes. The exemption amounts for taxable years from 2010 to 2017 are as follows: $72,450 in 2010, $74,450 in 2011, $78,250 in 2012, $81,450 in 2013, $85,050 in 2014, $88,650 in 2015, $92,650 in 2016, and $96,550 in 2017. In 2017, the exemption amount was $96,550, which increased to $100,950 in 2018, $105,150 in 2019, and $109,950 in 2020. Taxpayers described in paragraph (1)(B) for tax purposes. The exemption amounts for taxable years from 2010 to 2017 are as follows: $47,450 in 2010, $48,450 in 2011, $50,350 in 2012, $51,950 in 2013, $53,750 in 2014, $55,550 in 2015, $57,550 in 2016, and $59,500 in 2017. In 2017, the exemption amount was $59,500, which increased to $61,700 in 2018, $63,800 in 2019, and $66,200 in 2020. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to provide Alternative Minimum Tax Relief for Nonrefundable Credits, limiting the aggregate amount of credits allowed for the taxable year based on the taxpayer's regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55(a). Conforming amendments are made to the Adoption credit sections of the Code. Section 23(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to adjust the limitation on tax credits for taxable years, allowing excess credits to be carried over to the following year. Additionally, the Child Tax Credit section is revised. The Child Tax Credit section of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to remove paragraph (3) and make adjustments to references to other sections. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust various tax credits, including the removal of certain paragraphs and subsections related to home mortgages, savers' credit, and residential energy efficient property. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust various tax credits, including plug-in electric vehicles and alternative motor vehicle credits. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust tax credits for plug-in electric vehicles, including a new qualified plug-in electric vehicle credit and changes to the foreign tax credit. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to adjust tax credits for plug-in electric vehicles, including a new qualified plug-in electric vehicle credit and changes to the foreign tax credit. The amendments include redesignating subsections (j), (k), and (l) as subsections (i), (j), and (k), respectively, and allowing for the carryforward of unused credits to the succeeding taxable year. These amendments will apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009.
